articles.headline: T.S.A. Experiments With Behavior Screening
articles.snippet: Behavior detection officers observe and talk to passengers for signs of trouble. Such officers, some with explosive-sniffing dogs, already routinely survey checkpoint lines.
articles.abstract: Behavior detection officers observe and talk to passengers for signs of trouble. Such officers, some with explosive-sniffing dogs, already routinely survey checkpoint lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration is taking another step back from its one-size-fits-all security screening that requires all airline passengers to remove their belts, shoes and coats at checkpoints.

articles.headline: Hints of Syrian Chemical Push Set Off Global Effort to Stop It
articles.snippet: In a show of international cooperation that involved Russia and Iraq, Syria was persuaded to stop chemical bomb preparation. But the United States and Europe are not resting easy.
articles.abstract: In a show of international cooperation that involved Russia and Iraq, Syria was persuaded to stop chemical bomb preparation. But the United States and Europe are not resting easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the last days of November, Israel’s top military commanders called the Pentagon to discuss troubling intelligence that was showing up on satellite imagery: Syrian troops appeared to be mixing chemicals at two storage sites, probably the deadly nerve gas sarin, and filling dozens of 500-pounds bombs that could be loaded on airplanes.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Banks to Pay $8.5 Billion to Speed Up Housing Relief
articles.snippet: Years of wrangling over flawed mortgages and foreclosures will come to an end for the 10 banks who settled with the federal government.
articles.abstract: Years of wrangling over flawed mortgages and foreclosures will come to an end for the 10 banks who settled with the federal government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Monday reached an $8.5 billion settlement with 10 major lenders to resolve claims of foreclosure abuses, including the use of flawed paperwork and bungled loan modifications that may have led to wrongful evictions.

articles.headline: Easing of Rules for Banks Acknowledges Reality
articles.snippet: Less stringent capital and liquidity requirements for banks for the world’s banks will help bolster the global economic recovery, which is needed most right now.
articles.abstract: Less stringent capital and liquidity requirements for banks for the world’s banks will help bolster the global economic recovery, which is needed most right now.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a global committee of regulators and central bankers agreed to a new set of rules for the banking system a year and a half ago, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, told The Financial Times, “I’m very close to thinking the United States shouldn’t be in Basel anymore. I would not have agreed to rules that are blatantly anti-American.”

articles.headline: In Japan, a Painfully Slow Sweep
articles.snippet: Much of Japan’s post-Fukushima cleanup is primitive, slapdash and bereft of the cleanup methods lauded by scientists as effective in removing radioactive cesium.
articles.abstract: Much of Japan’s post-Fukushima cleanup is primitive, slapdash and bereft of the cleanup methods lauded by scientists as effective in removing radioactive cesium.
articles.lead_paragraph: NARAHA, Japan — The decontamination crews at a deserted elementary school here are at the forefront of what Japan says is the most ambitious radiological cleanup the world has seen, one that promised to draw on cutting-edge technology from across the globe.

articles.headline: Mobile Apps Drive Rapid Change in Searches
articles.snippet: Devices like tablets and smartphones have transformed the way people use the Internet, making the dominance of a company like Google potentially more precarious than it seems.
articles.abstract: Devices like tablets and smartphones have transformed the way people use the Internet, making the dominance of a company like Google potentially more precarious than it seems.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the Federal Trade Commission decided last week to close its antitrust investigation of Google without charges, one important factor, though hardly mentioned, was just beneath the surface: the mobile revolution.

articles.headline: Rescued by a  Bailout, A.I.G. May Sue Its Savior
articles.snippet: A lawsuit claims that the rescue by the government deprived A.I.G.’s shareholders of tens of billions of dollars and took private property for public use without appropriate compensation.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit claims that the rescue by the government deprived A.I.G.’s shareholders of tens of billions of dollars and took private property for public use without appropriate compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fresh from paying back a $182 billion bailout, the American International Group has been running a nationwide advertising campaign with the tagline “Thank you America.”
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced
